comments:
Computers have become an essential tool in nearly all organizations; no management student's education is complete without acquiring knowledge about using computers to solve management problems. The course is intended to build a solid foundation and develop comfort in using the computer to solve problems, teach management software tools for course work and professional life, and provide an understanding of the role of computers in modern organizations. Topics include budgeting, analytical modeling, sensitivity analysis, database management, decision analysis, optimization, neural networks, and simulation. The new course format incorporates all previous recitation material into lectures. The recitation or lab section has been replaced with an open laboratory policy that allows students to complete labs at their convenience. Three weekly one hour lectures provide conceptual and analytical material as well as practical tutorials on using Microsoft Excel. Students complete six realistic cases playing the role of solving a problem for a client using Microsoft Excel and PowerPoint. No prior background in either computers or operations and information management is expected.

Many students found the course challenging and time-consuming, but nonetheless worthwhile and applicable. Several students found the class poorly structured despite the extensive effort to revamp the course. Others, however, found that the new format was “student-friendly,” and the “efforts to improve the class have really paid off.” According to one student, “This course offers a great deal of useful techniques and covers a diversity of information that aid general processes in critical thinking and decision making.” 

Students found that Professor Clemons and Professor Hitt complemented each other well. Students mentioned that Professor Hitt’s lectures were logical, concise and straightforward, and Professor Clemons’ were engaging and filled with personal stories and anecdotes. Some felt this dynamic left “a lot of the heavy lifting for Professor Hitt,” and would have preferred Professor Clemons to stay on topic a little bit more, even though he was “immensely interesting,” as one student put it. Overall, both professors received significantly more positive feedback than negative feedback.

Students widely disapproved of the participation component of the grading system, considering the large class size. Students also expressed displeasure with the length of problem sets and the time commitment required to complete them. OPIM 101 is one of the Wharton core courses.
